No, that's quite clear. So that means that the 18.6 billions that I've mentioned instead of 31.1 that we established, it's calculated exactly on a consistent methodology with the 34.8 that we have been publishing one year ago. So that means that in term of volatility, in term of all the different parameters, that's something absolutely consistent.
The question was related to liquidity premium in excess of the swap rate and volatility assumption at that point in time versus average.

Okay, the cost of – the impact of the liquidity premium that we took, i.e., 50 basis points for Europe, zero for Japan and 100 basis points for the U.S., it brought a bit more than four billion in term of EV.
. If I took say 10.6, I'd have to knock 4 billion to get it to exactly the same basis as last year..
If you believe that the point in time estimate of risk-free rates without illiquidity premium is the right measure, yes.

But you should take also into consideration the fact that this has been calculated at an extremely low point in term of interest rate and since then in the U.S., for example, we recovered something like 60 or 70 basis points. In Europe, we recovered something like 30 basis points. So that's why it's quite relevant with this type of illiquidity premium.
And on volatility can you explain what we did?
In volatility we did exactly the same as last year, so that means that we have taking the implied – the long term implied volatility that is calculated on average on one year.
Okay. So you did the same last year?
Exactly.
And the average volatility seems higher than the September 30 volatility.

Sorry, I think my questions have actually been – one of them has just been answered. If I could just – actually, it's Tony Silverman at Standard & Poor's Equity Research. On the volatility, what volatility does that mean you are using? Was there some assumption that it would return to a normal level over a period of time? One of your peer groups yesterday did that. Or was it an average over the past year?

And the second question was on the off-balance sheet property, which was 3.4 billion on the slide that was helpfully put up. I was wondering how that compares, how that relates to the 1.8 billion on page 7 of the EV report, which is again, is off-balance sheet capital gains. I don't know if one's before holding tax and the other is after?

Okay, let's start up with your question on volatilities. If you take the EV report on page 38, so you have all the explanation of what we take in term of volatility. So, as I tell you – as I told you it's implied volatility of market prices. It's on 5, 10, and 20 years for both equities and swaptions. Just as a matter of explanation of what I said before, if you take for example, the U.S., equity volatilities are 28.32%. Last year we were at 22.4. On the Euro zone at 10 years we are at 29.19, 1 year ago we are 24.6. And roughly speaking it's same for swaptions, it's even worse, because taking the U.S. 10 years we're at 16.12, whereas one year ago we were at 12.7.
The other question on equity – I'm sorry, real estate gains...
I think we can leave that aside that question's four in a call that......
What else? Ando another one? Sorry. Is there is someone in the back of the room or someone on the phone?
We have a question from Mrs. Emanuel Gala from Capstone. Please go ahead, ma'am.
Hello. Good morning. Sorry, good afternoon. Can you hear me?
Yes.

So if I may three questions. First on slide 47, you mention your sensitivities and you talk about 1% default on fixed income. Could you remind us where it is, which level, this 1%? The second question, sorry to come back on the U.S., but we understand that to offshore the U.S. is going to get some capital relief from the current regulator. Did you ask yourself for some capital relief? And more generally speaking is there any risk that the French regulator could change the view on capital needs for the U.S.? And the last question I see, Denis Duverne mentioned that on price for the shares they potentially would be one-third dilutive versus the ordinary shares, maybe I missed something there. Could you elaborate a little bit there? Thank you.

Okay. On the 1% default assumption it's a straight assumption. We have assumed that 1% of our corporate bond portfolio would default. So that's – there's no benchmark against that, just an expectation. That's a demonstration the sensitivity if 1% of our corporate bonds was to default. Second question in the U.S we happen to be in the state of New York, which is the most conservative, prudent, protective of policyholders of all the 50 states and we do not expect any particular capital relief. It is true that some of our U.S. competitors have obtained in some other states capital relief under conditions which have not been made public, and so we don't – there has been some numbers that have been mentioned, but clearly there is not a level playing field in the U.S. because we have different supervisors in each state, but we are regulated by New York.

As far as the French regulators are concerned in relation to the U.S, I don't know what you're talking about because the U.S. is applying the U.S. regulation. The French regulators, French supervisors are applying both the French supervisory rules and the European solvency rules from a conservative basis. They could potentially not allow us to transfer funds to the U.S., but this is not the case at this stage. So, I don't have any particular concern on this.

On the preference shares, we have just made a calculation of what the dilution would be if we were to issue equity versus preference shares. And our calculation tell us that equity would be three times as dilutive of preference shares. Or rather that preference shares would be three times less dilutive than equity. Because the – once we set the – because the preference shares are not convertible into straight equity and once we set the rate of a preference share it is set to us and there are limits to the amounts of dividend that we would pay which, in the last resolution, is 14%, a maximum of 14% of the nominal as an equivalent of interest. Whereas if you issue equity, you issue equity first with a discount. And then the dividends will grow with the earnings. So, that's the reason why the dilution is much less serious.
We have another question from...

Andrew Ritchie from Citadel. Just three very quick questions. First of all, could you just clarify in the 18.6 billion of EV as it would be on the old basis this year, what was the impact of the fair value of your own debt? And second question, in your capital structure, please remind us what bit is your capital structure loss absorbing? In other words, the perpetuals, and if you would issue preferreds, would they be loss-absorbing capital as well?

Okay. To answer your first question on the fair value of debt, so the fair value of debt and the end of the year. Assuming that we would take the the old methodology, the mark-to-market of that would be 2.9 billion. Where does it come from? You get the answer on page 43 of the specific appendix on this. It comes from the fact that we have super subordinated debt and most of these debts have been issued with a spread of 1.5%. Now we are far above this level, and so they are all – they all have a market price, which is close to 50%. So, that explains why we had a surge in the unrealized gain on this debt.
Would preferred be loss-absorbing was the second question?
Our debt, our existing debt is not loss-absorbing, and the preferred would be loss-absorbing. They would be loss-absorbing in proportion of the issuance premium.

Andrew Crean at Citi again. I just want to follow up on a question asked earlier. What is the U.S. RBC at December? And then a more general question on your investment philosophy currently. When, as corporate bonds mature and as net flows come in, are you reinvesting in corporate bonds at the same sort of grossing rates? Or have you been moving into govies in the fourth quarter to sort of protect yourself? Is that still the case? How are you viewing the current spreads? Are you running shy of them or taking a big benefit?
On the RBC in the U.S. it was 329% at year end. And on the re-investments, Gérald, you want to answer that?

We have been extremely cautious in the fourth quarter last year. So that means that we were mostly cash. As you can see in the presentation, Denis mentioned to you that we had a cash position about 40 billion. Nevertheless we are investing in corporate bonds, not exclusively. We are roughly speaking, as I said, 50% in the bonds, 50% in corporate bonds. We will slightly increase the corporate bonds and at least we reinvest in high-grade corporate bonds like senior debts from banks and from large corporate.

About the spread, you can see that in January there were some attractive new issues from the utilities. And for example, you have spreads. The spread was at 20 basis points. That's the kind of risk that we can take, and that keeps some significance off side in terms of interest rate. In the end what does it mean? That means that when you reinvest money, you can reinvest, you can offset and even be better off than you can offset most of the decline of the .
Roughly I would say that we are flat in terms of our reinvestment rate, it's very close to our existing rate right now.

Hello. , couple of very quick questions, I hope. I think Gérald said without liquidity premier the EV would have been four billion lower. Is there any kind of rough rule of thumb how you get from base incentives there to the four billion number you mentioned? So that's the first question.

And the second question, again, just to clarify on page, where's it gone, page 39 of the embedded value report, second paragraph there you talk about volatilities, swaptions and implied volatilities, et cetera, et cetera. You seem to imply you take an average number for the whole year 2008? I know I'm taking long here, but I vaguely remember last year that was the average for the last two weeks, wasn't it, no?

No. Okay. I start with your last question. So, last year it was absolutely consistent with the other decision that we took. We'd have done exactly the same. So the volatility level would have been the same last year. So your question, to be sure I understood your question on Page 10, your question is to see if the illiquidity premium has an impact on sensitivities in EV and NBV, is it right?
As stated, I was earlier trying to get some insights about the illiquidity premium.
Can you move the mike, please?

Earlier I was trying to get at what estimate that four billion number, playing around with some of the sensitivities on Page 10? And came to a number a bit over two billion rather than four billion. So I'm just wondering if going forward is there kind of a rough rule of thumb how you can use the sensitivities on Page 10?

Yes. Can we get the mike here in front? Technically it's not the same as the sensitivities on the interest rate, because what we do is we add 50 dilutes here, or 50 of undiluted on the curve that we use to project all the flow without changing the value of the assets, which means that it's hard to consequent that productivity at a higher range than less than 12% of sale. We have been out of the middle on the front options, this currency. But actually technically that's not the same as the interest rate you're . So there is no way you can reveal that using the sensitivities as they stand. So there is no way you can reveal that using the sensitivities as they stand.
Okay.
Another question? Do we have a question on the phone? Yes?
We have a question from Mr. Timan Zeckiff from Exam. Please go ahead, sir.

Hi. Good afternoon, gentlemen. We stopped to see some of your competitors during some goodwill impairments on their most recent acquisitions. Do you see any reason to follow this trend in the coming quarters? And my second question is related to the view you have on your competitive position regarding the credited rates on live products, especially in Continental Europe? Do you think that the rates you're bearing they currently are effective enough to keep the commercial momentum? Thank you.

On goodwill impairments, and we are as you have seen we have not incurred any goodwill at the end of '08 because we didn't feel it was appropriate to do that. We will review the situation in each of the coming periods and the question is going to be a judgment as to whether the change in market conditions is something that is going to continue for quite a long time or is temporary.

When I look at our most recent acquisitions in the face of Mexico, I don't see any reason to have any particular concern because this company was not making money when we bought it. It made a little bit of money in the first six months and we expect it to be improving its profitability quite rapidly in the next several years. In the case of Russia, it's a bit different because there was an expectation of high quotes of the motor markets in Russia. And even though we have a very profitable business, which is in line with the assumptions, if growth doesn't come back in Russia because IFRC would be permanently depressed. We would have to review the situation but it's too early to say anything more than that at this stage.

In terms of the complication on crediting rates, I suppose that you are asking the question in relation to France. We have – had a policy this year in France which is very consistent with the one of the previous years, which is that we are not the most competitive and never try to be the most competitive. We are among the companies that offer an attractive, I mean a different rate, which takes into account our financial strength, the investment income that we have earned with a quite good financial [management policy and the level of profitability that we want to give to the shareholders and we are in front in individual life in 2008. We have gained market share because the bank-insurers were losing market share. We believe that we have maintained our competitive position overall.
I think the important point today is, I mean, for the clients there is a slight equality. So I don't think we need to overpay. Is there another question on the phone. No? Thank you. In the room? Yes.

And it's Tony Silverman, Standard & Poor's Equity Research. Just to follow-up on an earlier question. How is the U.S. built into your – how does the French regulator build the U.S. into your Solvency I required capital?

The U.S. is built exactly the same way as any other business. It's treated as if it was a French business or as if it was an E.U. business. So the solvency requirement is based on the reserves and the solvency available is determined at the Group liquidity level.
How – the follow-up question would be how those, what you actually use doing that relate to the NAIC minimum? Is it something like one time? Or something like two times that?

When you look at the addition of resource and capital in the U.S. system and resource and capital as determined in our European Solvency regime, they are about the same with a gap of something like 500 million. So it's quite close.
All right. Thank you.
Yes. There.

Thanks, final question for me. I am just a bit confused on what the trigger point for, during this , on the one hand you said rating agencies may downgrade but it's only not by much and you wouldn't spend anyway. You said your Solvency margin is pretty well above the hundred. Sounds like the regulator is allowing for soft factors which could amount to 2, 3, 4 billion. So under what circumstances are you going to raise capital, equity, or non-equity?

Okay. Remember Greenspan's answer when asked a total similar question? I think the – don't expect us to give a precise trigger point. There is no reason. We will do it when we feel it's appropriate if there is a need. If there is a need. At this stage we don't think there is a need. Okay? So the way we, the way you have to look at it is I think quite simple, what we are telling you is we are adding an instrument to the toolkit, which is an instrument which can be used in case of necessity and which is less diluted than ordinary shares.

We also tell you that the mutuals have significant resources and we'd be ready to go and underwrite that if needed but that other people could also underwrite them, I mean the market, therefore we have this fair resolution. When would we use it? I'm not going to go beyond the answer but we'll use it if we think we need it, the day when we will use it. Points. What are the driving elements? The regulators can ask us for more capital if they become uncomfortable in a sort of cushy world. It's not the case today. So that's it. Okay?

Thanks, just to follow-up on that then. How concerned or unconcerned are you about the tangibility of your capital? Something that's often talked about it's gone, it's roughly gone down by 50% and you're talking about adding potentially further non-equity capital to the base, which would potentially increase, increase the leverage for ordinary shareholders?

Yes, what we've been telling you is also very simple. It's clear that the margins there are not what they used to be in normal market circumstances, but we are also going through very difficult times. What are the key driving forces? The key driving forces are what are the regulators asking you to have to underwrite your business? That's it. And preferred shares would be admissible to satisfy the regulatory requirements.

This whole discussion about tangibility is a red herring frankly because we've been a company that hasn't made acquisitions over the last 20 years, we have significant amounts of DBI which is a real asset and DBO, which is a real asset if we continue to write new business. And frankly, you cannot buy a life company without paying dividend, unless you buy a run off, essentially. So this is, I mean, I don't think it's really a serious point. Yes.

Please, question on Page 71, the slides, the ABS stuff. You say Level 3 represents about 15%. I mean what do you see happening for that going forward?

No more questions.
1.5 for the overall portfolio and 15 for the ABS. So ABS is 15, 1.5 – so sorry – it's not a typo, it's 1.5 for the whole bond portfolio and 15 for the ABS.
And the number for the half-year was what?
The number for the half-year was about the same. It was 1.4 or something like that. So it did not change there much.
